DT Article
TI Protozoa and digestive tract parameters in Blue wildebeest (Connochaetes
   taurinus) and Black wildebeest (Connochaetes gnou), with description of
   Entodinium taurinus n. sp.
AU Booyse, Dirk G.
   Dehority, Burk A. (dirk.booyse@up.ac.za) 
SO European Journal of Protistology
VL 48
IS 4
PS 283-289
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Rumen contents from four blue wildebeest (Connochaetes taurinus) and six
   black wildebeest (Connochaetes gnou) were collected from two locations
   during two winter culling seasons. A total of 16 species of Protozoa
   were found in blue wildebeest with Dasytricha ruminantium,
   Opisthotrichum janus and Ostracodinium gracile occurring in all four
   animals. In black wildebeest, 23 species of Protozoa were observed with
   only Diplodinium bubalidis (caudal spine morphotype) and Ostracodinium
   damaliscus being present in all animals. In the blue wildebeest, the
   total number of species in an individual animal varied from 9 to 11 and
   in the black wildebeest, the number ranged from 4 to 14. Concentrations
   of cells per ml ranged from 1110 to 5880 in the blue wildebeest and 3120
   to 6240 in the black wildebeest. This study is the first report on
   Protozoa species in the blue and black wildebeest. A new species of
   Entodinium is described, Entodinium taurinus n. sp., observed in the
   rumen contents of three blue wildebeest. Several physical parameters of
   the digestive tract were also measured, including distribution, pH and
   density of gastrointestinal contents in different sections of the total
   tract. In vitro gas production was estimated for rumen, cecum and colon
   contents. [copyright] 2012 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI NEW CANCELLARIIDAE (MOLLUSCA, GASTROPODA) FROM THE MIOCENE GATUN
   FORMATION OF PANAMA, WITH ELEVEN NEW SPECIES.
AU Landau, Bernard (bernielandau@sapo.pt) 
   Petit, Richard E.
   da Silva, Carlos M.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 6
PS 907-930
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Thirty species of Cancellariidae in 11 genera from the Miocene Gatun
   Formation in the Panama Canal area, Caribbean Panama, are discussed
   including two species not represented by specimens suitable for formal
   description. The following 11 species are described as new: Cancellaria
   harzhauseri n. sp., Cancellaria mixta n. sp., Bivetiella dilatata n.
   sp., Euclia alacertata n. sp., Pyruclia tweedledum n. sp., Pyruclia
   tweedledee n. sp., Massyla toulai n. sp., Aphera aphrodite n. sp.,
   Axelella cativa n. sp., Agatrix agathe n. sp., Ventrilia coatesi n. sp.
   This assemblage of cancellariids is very diverse and highly endemic,
   with 18 (60 percent) species found only in the Miocene Gatun Formation.
   These assemblages all lie within the Gatunian Neogene Paciphile
   Molluscan Unit 1 (GNPMU1).

DT Article
TI NEW UINTASORICINE (?PRIMATES, PLESIADAPIFORMES) FROM THE EARLIEST
   BRIDGERIAN, LATEST EARLY EOCENE OF WYOMING.
AU Gunnell, Gregg F. (gregg.gunnell@duke.edu) 
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 6
PS 973-978
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Uintasoricines are diminutive plesiadapiforms that are found in the
   latest Paleocene through middle Eocene, predominantly in North America.
   They are not a diverse group but individual species may be locally
   abundant and they are a persistent element of the plesiadapiform
   radiation in North America surviving over a span of approximately 16
   million years. Recent field work in southern Wyoming at South Pass has
   led to the discovery of a new genus and species of uintasoricine. The
   new form is smaller in tooth dimensions compared to other known
   uintasoricines, being slightly smaller than Uintasorex montezumicus from
   California. Both the newly described taxon and U. montezumicus are among
   the smallest plesiadapiforms yet known with body weights estimated to be
   20 to 25 g. The sediments of the Cathedral Bluffs Tongue of the Wasatch
   Formation at South Pass contain a unique upland fauna-the presence of a
   distinctive uintasoricine in this assemblage adds further evidence to
   support the notion that this upland environment was a biodiversity
   hotspot during the latest early Eocene.
C1 Gunnell, Gregg F.; Duke Lemur Ctr, Div Fossil Primates, Durham, NC,
   27705, USA, USA.
EM gregg.gunnell@duke.edu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0022-3360

   region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene

   Bartelsia pentadactyla [Wyoming /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Plesiadapiformes [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Wyoming /  / ] [Eocene /
   Bridgerian / ].

   973; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A POSSIBLE TRACEMAKER FOR ARTHROPHYCUS ALLEGHANIENSIS.
AU McCoy, Victoria E. (victoria.mccoy@yale.edu) 
   Strother, Paul K.
   Briggs, Derek E.G.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 6
PS 996-1001
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 13
AB Arthrophycus alleghaniensis is a well-known trace fossil common in the
   lower Silurian of the Appalachian Basin, eastern U.S.A. Despite the
   distinctive morphology of this trace, with few exceptions, hypotheses
   about the nature of the tracemaker have not extended beyond that of a
   long-bodied, segmented organism. A single organic compression of a
   long-bodied arthropod discovered in shale interbedded with sandstones
   containing A. alleghaniensis in the Silurian (Llandovery) Tuscarora
   Formation at Mann Narrows, Pennsylvania is described. The specimen
   preserves evidence of two trunk tagmata: an anterior tagma with tergites
   extending into broad, rectangular pleurae, and a posterior tagma bearing
   long, curved spines. Head and appendages are not preserved. The new
   arthropod, Pleuralata spinosa n. gen. n. sp., matches the size and
   general morphology required for an A. alleghaniensis tracemakcr. Precise
   systematic affinities of this new arthropod could not be determined.
   This discovery supports the conclusion that the tracemakers of various
   Arthrophycus ichnospecies are likely poorly preserved, and presently
   unknown, members of the Ecdysozoa.
C1 McCoy, Victoria E.; Yale Univ, Dept Geol & Geophys, POB 208109, New
   Haven, CT, 06520, USA, USA.
EM victoria.mccoy@yale.edu
OI Strother, Paul/0000-0003-0550-1704

   Lower Silurian / ].

   possible tracemaker] [Pennsylvania /  / new species] [ / Appalachian

DT Article
TI A NEW EARLY DANIAN GASTROPOD ASSEMBLAGE FROM NORTHERN PATAGONIA, RIO
   NEGRO PROVINCE, ARGENTINA.
AU del Rio, Claudia Julia (claudiajdelrio@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 6
PS 1002-1016
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new early Danian gastropod assemblage contained in the Roca Formation
   of Rio Negro Province was analyzed. Eleven species are described and
   illustrated, the new genus Rocalaria is created, and six new species are
   recognized: Gyroscala daniana, Heteroterma carmeloi, Microfulgur
   concheyroae, Sulcobuccinum prominentum, Cidarina lenzaniyeuensis, and
   Rocalaria alani. The present research includes the first mention of
   Sulcobuccinum d'Orbigny, 1850, Priscoficus Conrad, 1866, Cavoscala
   Whitfield, 1892, Microfulgur Finlay and Marwick, 1937, and Cidarina
   Dall, 1909, for the Danian of Southern South America; the new record of
   Austrophaera Furque and Camacho, 1949, Fusinus Rafinesque, 1815 and
   Heteroterma Gabb, 1869 in northern Patagonia; and the oldest Paleogene
   record for the genus Gyroscala de Boury, 1887. The presence of the study
   assemblage in northern Patagonia indicates a more complex
   paleobiogeographic pattern for the area than previously thought, as
   shown by the record of endemic genera, cosmopolitan taxa, elements with
   Tethyan/Indo-Pacific affinities, and genera related with "Wangaloan"
   faunas of the Paleocene of New Zealand.

DT Article
TI A NEW PRIMITIVE SPECIES OF THE FLAT-HEADED PECCARY PLATYGONUS
   (TAYASSUIDAE, ARTIODACTYLA, MAMMALIA) FROM THE LATE MIOCENE OF THE HIGH
   PLAINS.
AU Prothero, Donald R. (donaldprothero@att.net) 
   Grenader, Jessica
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 6
PS 1021-1031
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of the Pliocene-Pleistocene flat-headed peccary,
   Platygonus pollenae, has been recovered latest Hemphillian (latest
   Miocene) localities from Nebraska, Kansas, Colorado, and Texas. It can
   be distinguished from other tayassuids by its distally rounded wing-like
   zygomatic process, and its subzygodont cheek teeth. In contrast to more
   derived species of Platygonus, it is much smaller in size, its molars
   are relatively more bunodont, the talon and talonid cusps are retained
   on the premolars of most individuals, and the mandibular symphysis lacks
   a median keel on the chin. In these characters, it is the earliest and
   the most primitive species of Platygonus known. It is more primitive
   than the typical Blancan species, or any of the species from the
   Pleistocene, and demonstrates the origin of this important Pleistocene
   mammal in the latest Miocene.
C1 Prothero, Donald R.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Vertebrate Paleontol, 900
   Exposit Blvd, Los Angeles, CA, 90007, USA, USA.
EM donaldprothero@att.net
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0022-3360

   America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene

   /  / ] [Texas /  / ] [Miocene /  / Kansas & Texas] [ /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Tayassuidae

DT Article
TI PROETID TRILOBITES FROM THE LOWER DEVONIAN (PRAGIAN) IHANDAR FORMATION,
   ANTI-ATLAS, MOROCCO.
AU Johnson, Robert G. (johnsonrg@btinternet.com) 
   Fortey, Richard A.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 6
PS 1032-1050
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 24
AB Proetid trilobites of Lower Devonian (Pragian) age are known principally
   from fragmentary material from the type area in the Czech Republic and
   Morocco. We describe well-preserved, articulated specimens from the
   Ihandar Formation of the Anti-Atlas, Morocco, which include species of
   previously little known genera, and help to clarify their morphology.
   Eight new species are described: Dalejeproetus sagaouii, D. owensi,
   Lepidoproetus maharchianus, L. lahceni, L. splendens, Podoliproetus
   mirdani, P. sinespina, and Proetina ihamadii.
C1 Johnson, Robert G.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Palaeontol, Cromwell Rd,

TI NEW TETHYAN APIOCRINITIDAE (CRINOIDEA, ARTICULATA) FROM THE JURASSIC OF
   ISRAEL.
AU Ausich, William I. (ausich.l@osu.edu) 
   Wilson, Mark A.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 6
PS 1051-1055
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Apiocrinites is described from the Middle Jurassic
   (Callovian) Matmor Formation of the Negev, Israel. Apiocrinites
   negevensis is from the tropical latitudes in the Tethys, in contrast to
   all other reported species of this genus. With a narrow radial facet and
   adjacent arms not in lateral contact and large aboral cup plates, A.
   negevensis is quite unusual for this genus.

DT Article
TI Morphological and molecular analysis of Myxobolus pharynae n. sp
   (Myxosporea) causing high mortality of Carassius auratus gibelio in pond
   aquaculture, China.
AU Lu Hong-da (hdlu@shou.edu.cn) 
   Cai Shui-ju
   Zhu You-ting
   Mao Mao
SO Marine Fisheries
VL 34
IS 4
PS 406-416
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Morphological and molecular characteristics of Myxosporean which have
   been causing high mortality of Allogynogenetic gibel carp (Carassius
   auratus gibelio) in pond aquaculture in Yancheng district, Jiangsu
   province, China in recent years were analyzed. The main characteristics
   were as follows : myxosporean was pyriform in frontal view, transparent
   mucous envelope was on the outside of spore, and 1 - 6 "V" - shaped
   edges were on the inner side of spore valve in the posterior part of
   some mature spores; two polar capsules were unequal; polar filament was
   coiled with 7 - 10 turns within the polar capsules; a long and thin
   intercapsular appendix was in the inner side of the anterior part of
   spore; iodinophilous vacuole was absent in the sporoplasm; the size was
   16. 82 [plus or minus] 0. 43(16. 03 - 17. 69) [mu]m in spore length, 10.
   26 [plus or minus] 0. 43 (9. 12 - 10. 88) [mu]m in spore breadth and 8.
   09 [plus or minus] 0. 29(7. 50 - 8. 75) [mu]m in spore thickness, 8. 66
   [plus or minus] 0. 25(8. 25 - 9. 16) [mu]m in the large polar capsule
   length, 3. 65 [plus or minus] 0. 25(3. 01 - 4. 19) [mu]m in the large
   polar capsule breadth and 8. 35 [plus or minus] 0. 28 (7. 60 - 8. 85)
   [mu]m in the small polar capsule length, 3.58 [plus or minus] 0. 23 (3.
   09 - 4. 11) [mu]m in the small polar capsule breadth, 1. 80 [plus or
   minus] 0. 12(1. 59 - 2. 00) [mu]m in the intercapsular appendix length.
   The pharynx of Carassius auratus gibelio was specifically infected. The
   size of sporocysts was 10 - 25 mm. 18S rDNA sequence generated for the
   spore by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was 1 576 bp long (GenBank
   JQ726700). There was no significant difference (P > 0. 05) in spore
   length between myxosporean in the study and M. psephurusi or M. twistus,
   and significant differences (P < 0. 05) in spore length between
   myxosporean in the study and M. ampullicapsulatus, M. wulii and M.
   aristichthydis respectively, and significant differences (P < 0. 05) in
   spore breadth and thickness, in polar capsules length and breadth
   between myxosporean in the study and M. ampullicapsulatus, M. wulii, M.
   psephurusi, M. twistus and M. aristichthydis respectively. Myxosporean
   in the study and M. ampullicapsulatus were closest relatives in the
   phylogenetic tree. Based on the comparison and analysis of spore
   morphology, host specificity, tissue or organ parasitized specificity,
   and 18S rDNA sequence, the myxosporean from the pharynx of Carassius
   auratus gibelio in the study was proved to be a new species, described
   as Myxobolus pharynae n. sp..
C1 Lu Hong-da; Shanghai Ocean Univ, Coll Fisheries & Life Sci, Shanghai,
   201306, China, China.
EM hdlu@shou.edu.cn
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1004-2490
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China
DE Carassius auratus gibelio [Myxozoan parasites / Myxobolus pharynae / New
   parasite species] [Jiangsu /  / New myxozoan parasite species]. 
   Myxobolus pharynae [Piscean hosts / Carassius auratus gibelio / New
   parasite species] [Jiangsu /  / New species from piscean host]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae, Myxozoa, Myxosporea, Bivalvulida
OR Carassius auratus gibelio (Cyprinidae): [Host]. 
   Myxosporea (Myxozoa): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa, P.
   410]. 
   Myxobolus pharynae (Bivalvulida): [Sp nov, Jiangsu, Parasite of
   Carassius auratus gibelio (Pisces), p. 411; Parasite].

DT Article
TI Species composition of the nemertean genus Oerstedia (Nemertea:
   Hoplonemertea) in the Far Eastern seas of Russia.
AU Akhmatova, A.F. (tsher@bio.dvgu.ru) 
   Chernyshev, A.V.
   Zaslavskaya, N.I.
SO Biologiya Morya (Vladivostok)
VL 38
IS 6
PS 454-461
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Russian Journal of Marine
   Biology.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Species composition of the nemertean genus Oerstedia (Nemertea:
   Hoplonemertea) in the Far Eastern seas of Russia. A. F. Akhmatova1, A.
   V. Chernyshevi1,2, N. I. Zaslavskaya1,2 (1A.V. Zhirmunsky Institute of
   Marine Biology, Far East Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences,
   Vladivostok 690059; 2Far Eastern Federal University, Vladivostok 690600)
   According to published data, six species of the nemertean genus
   Oerstedia occur in the Russian Far Eastern seas. Molecular genetic (28S
   sequences) and allozyme (11 loci) analyses showed that O. oculata
   (Kulikova, 1987), O. zebra (Chernyshev, 1993), and O. valentinae
   (Chernyshev, 1993) are junior synonyms of O. polyorbis Iwata, 1954 but
   O. phoresiae (Kulikova, 1987) is a valid species. The validity of the
   species status of O. dorsal is sensu Iwata, 1954 is also confirmed. New
   data on the variability and distribution of some Oerstedia species are
   provided. (Biologiya Morya, 2012, vol. 38, no. 6, pp. 454-461).
C1 Akhmatova, A.F.; Russian Acad Sci, Far E Branch, Vladivostok, 690059,
   Russia, Russia.
EM tsher@bio.dvgu.ru
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology
SN 0134-3475
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Genetics; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Oerstedia [Molecular genetics /  / Systematics] [North Pacific / Russian
   Far East / distribution]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Nemertinea
OR Oerstedia (Nemertinea). 
   Oerstedia polyorbis - Iwata 1954 (Nemertinea): [Syn nov, Oerstedia
   oculata Kulikov 1987, p. 460; Syn nov, Oerstedia valentinae (Chernyshev
   1993), p. 460; Syn nov, Oerstedia zebra (Chernyshev 1993), p. 460].

DT Article
TI A first report of Sphenothallus Hall, 1847 in the Cambrian of Variscan
   Europe.
AU Fatka, Oldrich (fatka@natur.cuni.cz) 
   Kraft, Petr
   Szabad, Michal
SO Comptes Rendus Palevol
VL 11
IS 8
PS 539-547
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Ten specimens of two phosphatic fossils have been recently discovered in
   lower and middle portions of Middle Cambrian Jince Formation in the
   Czech Republic. They are attributed to the genus Sphenothallus Hall,
   1847 and described as two separate species; comparatively small conchs
   are described as S. kozaki sp. nov., the much larger specimens
   characterized by its smooth and partly flexible organo-phosphatic walls
   of shell are determined as ?S. kordulei sp. nov. Sphenothallus is known
   to range from Cambrian to Permian and accommodates numerous species.
   However, its Cambrian distribution is considerably restricted. Generally
   rare specimens have been described from Lower to Middle Cambrian of
   Laurentia and from the Lower Cambrian of Gondwana and peri-Gondwana. The
   new record of Sphenothallus from the Jince Biota represents a notable
   extension of their geographic range. (C) 2012 Academie des sciences.
   Published by Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Fatka, Oldrich; Charles Univ, Fac Sci, Albertov 6, Prague, 12843 2,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM fatka@natur.cuni.cz
RI Kraft, Petr/I-6152-2017
OI Kraft, Petr/0000-0001-8868-925X; Fatka, Oldrich/0000-0003-1898-3319
SC Zoology
SN 1631-0683
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Sphenothallus [Czech Republic /  / new record] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
   Sphenothallus kozaki; Sphenothallus? kordulei [Czech Republic /  / new
   species] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Conulariida
OR Sphenothallus - Hall 1847 (Conulariida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Sphenothallus kozaki (Conulariida): [Sp nov, Czech Republic, Cambrian,
   P. 542; Fossil]. 
   Sphenothallus? kordulei (Conulariida): [Sp nov, Czech Republic,
   Cambrian, P. 542; Fossil].

DT Article
TI LERNANTHROPUS INDEFINITUS N. SP (COPEPODA, SIPHONOSTOMATOIDA,
   LERNANTHROPIDAE) PARASITIC ON ARGYROSOMUS REGIUS (ASSO, 1801) (PISCES,
   SCIAENIDAE).
AU Koyuncu, C. Erkin (ekoyuncu@mersin.edu.tr) 
   Castro Romero, Raul
   Karaytug, Suphan
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 85
IS 12-13
PS 1409-1420
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB Lernanthropus indefinitus n. sp. was found as a new parasite on
   Argyrosomus regius (Asso, 1801). The identity of L. indefinitus was
   determined on the basis of the morphological features of the female,
   such as the shape of the dorsal plate, shape and size of the fourth leg,
   length of the fifth leg, and shape and size of the parabasal flagellum.
   In addition, new data are reported for Lernanthropus kroyeri Van
   Beneden, 1851 on Dicentrarchus labrax (L., 1758), and some comments are
   added on the antennules and parabasal flagellum of L. kroyeri. The
   present paper raises the number of known species of Lernanthropidae in
   Turkish waters to seven.
C1 Koyuncu, C. Erkin; Mersin Univ, Fac Fisheries, Yenisehir Campus, Mersin,
   TR-33169, Turkey, Turkey.

TI DESCRIPTION OF STEPHOS BOETTGERSCHNACKAE SP NOV., A NEW COPEPOD
   (CALANOIDA, STEPHIDAE) FROM AN ANCHIALINE CAVE IN THE ADRIATIC SEA.
AU Krsinic, F. (fkrsinic@izor.hr) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 85
IS 12-13
PS 1525-1539
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of calanoid copepod, Stephos boettgerschnackae, was
   collected from an anchialine cave in the Kvarner region (Croatia). This
   is the first record of the genus from the Adriatic Sea. The new species
   is distinguished from other Stephos spp. by a combination of the
   following features: last pedigerous somite asymmetrical; female genital
   double-somite asymmetrical in ventral view and slightly longer than
   wide, single operculum with posteriorly a spiniform process; antennules
   of both sexes symmetrical, 24-segmented, and very long, reaching almost
   to end of caudal rami; antennal exopod 7-segmented; maxillule with 14
   armature elements on praecoxal arthrite; female 5th legs symmetrical,
   uniramous, and 3-segmented, terminal segment armed with spinules
   distally along inner and outer margin, transverse comb of spinules at
   mid-length, single small spine on anterior surface; male 5th legs
   uniramous and asymmetrical, right leg 4-segmented, left 5-segmented with
   segment 4 hardly swollen and segment 5 very complex.
C1 Krsinic, F.; Inst Oceanog & Fisheries Split, Ivana Mestrovica 63, Split,
   HRV-21001, Croatia, Croatia.
EM fkrsinic@izor.hr
SC Zoology

   Atlantic

DT Article
TI PSEUDOTHELPHUSA ZONGOLICAE (DECAPODA, PSEUDOTHELPHUSIDAE), A NEW SPECIES
   OF FRESHWATER CRAB FROM VERACRUZ, MEXICO.
AU Alvarez, Fernando (falvarez@ibiologia.unam.mx) 
   Villalobos, Jose L.
   Moreno, Eric
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 85
IS 12-13
PS 1541-1547
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB A new species of freshwater crab of the family Pseudothelphusidae from
   Zongolica, Veracruz, Mexico, is described. Only one previous report
   exists of a pseudothelphusid crab from the Zongolica region in central
   Veracruz, but that one belongs to a different tribe. The new species is
   placed in the genus Pseudothelphusa due to the evident torsion of the
   male gonopod and to the presence of the typical reniform caudo-marginal
   projection of Pseudothelphusa. The new species can be distinguished from
   its congeners by a gonopod with a caudo-marginal projection with a
   single large lobe, which extends proximally to reach beyond the middle
   of the gonopod's principal axis, and a conical prominence with terminal
   pore setae on the distal crest of the caudo-lateral surface. The new
   species represents the 26th species of the genus with affinities with
   species from the Pacific versant of Mexico.
C1 Alvarez, Fernando; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Biol, Apartado Postal
   70-153, Mexico City, DF, 04510, Mexico, Mexico.
EM falvarez@ibiologia.unam.mx
RI Alvarez, Fernando/G-6503-2018
OI Alvarez, Fernando/0000-0002-7347-5483; Villalobos Hiriart, Jose
   Luis/0000-0001-6810-2300
SC Zoology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura

AN ZOOR14908029989
DT Article
TI TETHYSBAENA OPHELICOLA N. SP (THERMOSBAENACEA), A NEW PRIME CONSUMER IN
   THE OPHEL BIOME OF THE AYYALON CAVE, ISRAEL.
AU Wagner, H.P. (drhpwagner@hotmail.com) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 85
IS 12-13
PS 1571-1587
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB A new species of the thermosbaenacean genus Tethysbaena Wagner, 1994 is
   described as T ophelicola n. sp. The species is an abundant inhabitant
   of the brackish, sulfidic warm-water pool of the remarkable karstic cave
   Ayyalon in Israel, with a chemosynthesis-based biome, named Ophel, where
   the new taxon feeds as a prime consumer in the food web on Beggiatoa
   bacterial mats. Common occurrence of females with the typical
   brood-pouches (often filled with manca stages) in all samples examined
   indicates, that the pool is not only a feeding ground, but indeed the
   natural environment of these animals. The new taxon, being part of the T
   relicta-group, is compared with its allegedly closest relatives, T
   relicta and T. somata. Some ecological data on the site and on the
   thermosbaenaceans in general are added.
C1 Wagner, H.P.; Andreas Coll, Dept Biol, Pieter Groen Bldg,POB 3226,
   Katwijk, NL-2220 CE, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM drhpwagner@hotmail.com
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Evolution; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Tethysbaena ophelicola [Israel /  / New species]. 
   Thermosbaenacea [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Peracarida, Thermosbaenacea

PT J
AN ZOOR14908029992
DT Article
TI TWO NEW CANDONID SPECIES FROM SOUTH KOREA (OSTRACODA, PODOCOPIDA).
AU Karanovic, I. (ivana.karanovic@utas.edu.au) 
   Lee, W.
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 85
IS 12-13
PS 1633-1656
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Candonidae from South Korea are poorly studied, and only nine species
   have been recorded so far. Here we describe Cypria asiatica sp. nov. and
   Cryptocandona smithi sp. nov. The first species is the third
   representative of the genus reported from Korea and it belongs to a
   group of species of Cypria Zenker, 1854 with reduced swimming setae on
   the second antenna and without the marginal tubercles on the shell. The
   group comprises nine species distributed in the Holarctic. Cypria
   asiatica stands apart from eight other congeneric species by the
   presence of septa-like structures on the postero-dorsal end of the left
   valve. Based on the present observations and some previous studies of
   the subfamily Cyclocypridinae, we here draw attention to the chaetotaxy
   of the mandibular palp and the chaetotaxy of the fifth limb. The latter
   shows close similarity between Cyclocypridinae and Paracypridinae and
   urges further study of homology of setae on this leg between three
   candonid subfamilies. Cryptocandona smithi is the 14th known Recent
   species of its genus and the third reported from Korea. It is similar to
   C. tsukagoshii Smith, 2011 from Japan and C. pygmaea (Ekman, 1908) from
   Sweden. They all share a peculiar chaetotaxy of the seventh limb and an
   unusually long posterior seta on the uropodal ramus. The new species can
   be distinguished from the Swedish species by the morphology of the
   genital field, and from the Japanese by the shape of the carapace, the
   length of the f-seta on the seventh limb, and other details of the soft
   parts. We here report some abnormalities in the morphology of the
   antennule found in one specimen, and compare this with similar
   abnormalities reported for C. tsukagoshii and C. brehmi (Klie, 1934),
   and postulate that this may be a result of the regenerative process of
   the antennule after damage during development.
C1 Karanovic, I.; Hanyang Univ, Coll Nat Sci, Seoul, 133791, South Korea,
   South Korea.
EM ivana.karanovic@utas.edu.au
RI Lee, Wonchoel/L-9822-2018
OI Lee, Wonchoel/0000-0002-9873-1033
SC Zoology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cryptocandona smithi; Cypria asiatica [South Korea /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Cryptocandona smithi (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, South Korea, P. 1646]. 
   Cypria asiatica (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, South Korea, P. 1637]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14908029992
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14908031133
DT Article
TI PHYLOGENY AND CLASSIFICATION OF THE TRIBE DEUTERAGENIINI (HYMENOPTERA,
   POMPILIDAE: PEPSINAE).
AU Lelej, A.S. (lelej@biosoil.ru) 
   Loktionov, V.M.
SO Far Eastern Entomologist
VL 254
PS 1-15
PD November 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Phylogenetic analysis of 13 species from seven generic groups with genus
   Priocnemis as outgroup reveals the relationships: Priocnemis +
   (Stigmatodipogon + {(Deuteragenia + Mesagenia) + ((Winnemanella +
   Nipponodipogon) + (Myrmecodipogon + Dipogon))}). A tree generated from
   13 species of seven generic groups and Priocnemis as outgroup based on
   24 characters by TNT (new technology search) yielded a length 69 steps,
   CI of 0.86, RI of 0.84. Deuteragenia + Mesagenia form joint cluster with
   one synapomorphy; other groups are monophyletic. New generic
   classification of the tribe Deuterageniini is proposed: Deuteragenia
   Sustera, 1912, stat. resurr. (=Mesagenia Haupt, 1959, syn. n.), Dipogon
   Fox, 1897, Myrmecodipogon Ishikawa, 1965, stat. n., Nipponodipogon
   Ishikawa, 1965, stat. n., Stigmatodipogon Ishikawa, 1965, stat. n., and
   Winnemanella Krombein, 1962, stat. n. A new synonymy is proposed for
   Deuteragenia bokhaica (Lelej, 1986), comb. n. (=Dipogon antropovi Lelej,
   1995, syn. n. A list of 81 species of tribe Deuterageniini by genera
   Deuteragenia (54 species), Dipogon (14), Myrmecodipogon (3),
   Nipponodipogon (6), Stigmatodipogon (3), Winnemanella (1) is given. A
   new combinations are proposed for 56 species. Key to the genera of the
   tribe Deuterageniini is given.
C1 Lelej, A.S.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Biol & Soil Sci, Vladivostok, 22,
   Russia, Russia.
EM lelej@biosoil.ru
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1026-051X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Status; Key; Evolution
DE Deuterageniini [Phylogeny /  / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Pompiloidea, Pompilidae

PT J
AN ZOOR14908030093
DT Article
TI A new genus of the family Theraphosidae (Araneae: Mygalomorphae) with
   description of three new species from the Western Ghats of Karnataka,
   India.
AU Siliwal, Manju (manjusiliwal@gmail.com) 
   Gupta, Neha
   Raven, Robert
SO Journal of Threatened Taxa
VL 4
IS 14
PS 3233-3254
PD November 2012
PY 2012
UR http://threatenedtaxa.org
AW http://threatenedtaxa.org/ZooPrintJournal/2012/November/o306526xi123233-
   3254.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB In this paper, a new genus Neoheterophrictus gen. nov., with three new
   species, Neoheterophrictus crurofulvus sp. nov., N. sahyadri sp. nov.
   and N. uttarakannada sp. nov., is described from Uttara Kannada
   District, Karnataka, India. The new genus is close to Heterophrictus
   Pocock, 1900 and Plesiophrictus Pocock, 1899 but has multilobed
   spermathecae, which was consistent in all the three species and the
   males possessing double tibial spur. Natural history information for all
   the species described is provided. We transfer Plesiophrictus bhori
   Gravely, 1915 to Heterophrictus and synonymise P. mahabaleshwari
   Tikader, 1977 with Heterophrictus milleti Pocock, 1900.
C1 Siliwal, Manju; Wildlife Informat Liaison Dev Soc, 96 Kumudham
   Nagar,Vilankuruchi Rd, Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, 641035, India, India.
EM manjusiliwal@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0974-7893; 0974-7907
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Neoheterophrictus crurofulvus; Neoheterophrictus sahyadri;
   Neoheterophrictus uttarakannada [Karnataka /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

   from Plesiophrictus, p. 3253]. 
   Heterophrictus mahabaleshwari - (Tikader 1977) (Araneae): [Comb nov,

   Heterophrictus milleti Pocock 1900, p. 3253].

   3234].

AN ZOOR14908030101
DT Article
TI Parambassis waikhomi, a new species of glassfish (Teleostei: Ambassidae)
   from Loktak Lake, northeastern India.
AU Geetakumari, K. (geetameme@gmail.com) 
   Basudha, C.
SO Journal of Threatened Taxa
VL 4
IS 14
PS 3327-3332
PD November 2012
PY 2012
UR http://threatenedtaxa.org
AW http://threatenedtaxa.org/ZooPrintJournal/2012/November/o306026xi123327-
   3332.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Parambassis waikhomi, a new species of glassfish from Loktak Lake,
   Chindwin basin in Manipur, northeastern India is distinguished from its
   congeners by the presence of 58-60 lateral line scales; two predorsal
   bones; a vertically elongated humeral spot; 24 vertebrae; maxilla
   reaching to 1/3 of the orbit; 8.2-10.9 interorbital width; four
   preorbital ridge, 11 preorbital edge, six supraorbital ridge, 18 serrae
   at lower edge of preoperculum, 24 serrae at hind margin of preoperculum.
   The species differs from its nearest congener P. ranga by the presence
   of 9-10 (vs. 12-13) pectoral fin rays and 19-20 (vs. 22-28) gill rakers.
C1 Geetakumari, K.; ICAR, Res Complex NEH Reg Manipur Ctr, Lamphelpat
   Imphal, Manipur, 795004, India, India.
EM geetameme@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0974-7893; 0974-7907
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Parambassis [India /  / Key to species]. 
   Parambassis waikhomi [Manipur /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Ambassidae
OR Parambassis - Bleeker (Ambassidae): [Key to species, India, P. 3331]. 
   Parambassis waikhomi (Ambassidae): [Sp nov, Manipur, P. 3328].

TI A new species of the genus Bifurcia (Araneae: Linyphiidae) from China.
AU Quan Dan
   Chen Jian (chenjian_hb@tom.com) 
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 21
IS 2
PS 65-67
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Bifurcia (Araneae: Linyphiidae), is described
   and illustrated on the basis of the specimens collected from Chongqing
   Municipality of China. The type specimen of this new species is
   deposited in College of Life Science, Xinan University. Bifurcia
   pseudosongi sp. nov. Holotype 2 [female], Mt, Jinyan, Chongqing
   Municipality, April 5, 2010. This new species is similar to Bifurcia
   cucurbita Zhai & Zhu, 2007 and Bifurcia songi Zhai & Zhu, 2007 in the
   shape of the scape, but differs from them by the undeveloped posterior
   median plate of epigynum.

DT Article
TI A new species of genus Anyphaena from China (Araneae: Anyphaenidae).
AU Feng Ping
   Ma Yan-Yan
   Yang Zi-Zhong (Yangzzh@yahoo.com.cn) 
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 21
IS 2
PS 72-75
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species, Anyphaena rhynchophysa sp. nov., is described from China.
   Color character photos of this new species are provided here in.
   Material is deposited in the Biological Herbarium of Dali University.
   All measurements are in millimeters (mm) Anyphaena rhynchophysa sp. nov.
   (Figs. 1-9) Type material. Holotype male, Nature Reserve of
   Gaoligongshan Mountain, Pianma Township, Lushui County, Nujiang, Yunnan
   Province, 26[degree] 00' 47.11''N, 98[degree] 39' 01.3''E, 2 166 m, 18
   April 2011, Ping Feng leg.; Paratype, 1 female, Nature Reserve of
   Gaoligongshan Mountain, Nankang Conservation Station, Tengchong County,
   Yunnan Province, 27[degree] 49' 46.4''N, 98[degree] 46' 25.3'', 2 000 m,
   22 April 2011, Ping Feng leg. Etymology. The specific name derived from
   irhynch', means bird beak, referring to the beak-like distal part of
   male conductor. Diagnosis. This new species resembles Anyphaena wuyi
   Zhang, Zhu et Song, 2005 (Zhang, Zhu et Song, 2005), but can be
   distinguished by the following characters: (1) male tergulum median
   apophysis arc-shaped at distal part, and cone-shaped at medial side
   (Figs. 5-6), different from the latter which are truncate at distal
   part, and bifurcate at medial side; (2) male conductor podgy, with
   beak-like tip (Figs. 6-7), but not the same as that of the latter, long
   and applanate; (3) female epigynum with nearly heart-shaped atrium (Fig.
   8), not quadrate; (4) spermatheca big and gourd-shaped (Fig. 9), while
   that of the latter is reniform.
C1 Yang Zi-Zhong; Dali Univ, Key Lab Med Insects & Spiders Resources Dev &
   Uti, Dali, Yunnan Province, 671000, China, China.
EM Yangzzh@yahoo.com.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1005-9628
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Anyphaena rhynchophysa [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Anyphaena rhynchophysa (Araneae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 74]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14907026429
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14907026430
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Parasitus and a new species of the genus
   Gamasodes (Acari: Mesostigmata: Parasitidae).
AU Ma Li-Ming (lmmabc@msn.com) 
   Bai Xue-Li
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 21
IS 2
PS 76-82
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Parasitus and a new species of the genus
   Gamasodes are described in the present paper. Type specimens are
   deposited in the Entomology Gallery, Institute of Microbiology and
   Epidemiology, Academy of Military Medical Sciences, Beijing. 1 Parasitus
   simplendogynii sp. nov. (Figs. 1-3) Female. Length of idiosoma 914-946
   (av. 928) [mu]m, Width 516-538 (av. 527) [mu]m. Anterior dorsal shield
   with 22 pairs of setae, D1, D3 and M2 long and pilose, M2 the longest,
   remaining setae short and simple, ET1 and ET2 minute. Posterior dorsal
   shield with more than 20 pairs of setae, pilose or simple. Presternal
   shields 1 pair, small, situated at out of tritosternal base. St1
   bifurcate, inserting on a pair of small sclerites; St2, St3 and 2 pairs
   of pores on sternal shield. MSt and the 3rd pair of pores on metasternal
   shields. Genital shield with 1 pair of setae. Interior tine of
   metasternal shields short and narrow, endogynium simple, shown in Fig.
   1B. Ventro-anal shield with 10 pairs of ventral setae and 3 perianal
   setae, of which 3 pairs of ventral setae pilose. Ad situated at level of
   posterior margin of anus, subequal to anus in length, PA longer than
   anus, pilose. Peritreme reaching to posterior part of coxa I anteriorly.
   Tectum 3 pronged, medial prong longer. Movable digit of chela
   tridentate, fixed digit with several denticles. Seta al of palpfemur
   bifurcate, al1 and al2 of palpgenu entire. Legs setae simple. Tarsus
   II-IV with 4 apical spines respectively. Male. Length of idiosoma 828 -
   849 (av. 839) [mu]m, width 441 - 452 (av. 446) [mu]m. Anterior dorsal
   shield with 22 pairs of setae, posterior dorsal shield with about 26
   pairs of setae, dorsal setae as in female. Presternal shields 1 pair,
   triangular. Holoventral shield with 3 pairs of sternal setae, 1 pair of
   metasternal setae, 1 pair of genital setae, about 20 pairs of ventral
   setae, 3 perianal setae and 3 pairs of pores, of which 3 pairs of
   ventral setae and PA pilose. Tectum 3 pronged, medial prong far longer
   than lateral ones. Movable digit of chela unidentate. Leg II with 2
   large spurs on femur, a double-headed small spurs on genu and tibia
   respectively. The new species belong to consanguineus-group, genus
   Parasitus Latreille, but differs from all known species of the group by
   simple endogynium, shown in Fig. 1B. Holotype [female], paratypes 2
   [female] [female], 2 [male] and 1 deutonymph, ex cow dung, from Jingyuan
   County (35[degree] 26' N, 106[degree] 24' E), Ningxia Hui Autonomous
   Region, 5 Oct. 2011. Name of the new species from "simpl-" (simple) and
   "endogynii" (endogynium). 2 Gamasodes jingyuanensis sp. nov. (Figs. 4-5)
   Deutonymph. Length of idiosoma 763 - 806 (av. 781) [mu]m, Width 538 -
   570 (av. 555) [mu]m. Anterior dorsal shield with 19 pairs of setae, F1,
   D1, D3 and M2 long and pilose, M2 the longest, remaining setae short and
   simple, ET1, ET2 and M1 minute, ET2, M1 and M3 on cuticle from the
   shield. Posterior dorsal shield with 14 pairs of setae, of which 2 pairs
   of setae long and pilose, remains short and simple. Presternal shields 1
   pair, rectangular. Sternal shield reticulated, with 4 pairs of setae and
   3 pairs of pores. Metapodal shields 1 pair, semicircular. Peritreme
   reaching to middle of coxa I anteriorly. Tectum triangular, with several
   denticles at lateral margins. Seta al of palpfemur stout seta-like, al1,
   and al2 of palpgenu spoon-shaped. Legs setae short and simple. Femur of
   leg II with 2 spurs, genu and tibia with a spur respectively, tarsus
   with 2 spurs, of which a spur long spiniform. Tarsus II-IV with 4
   subapical setae respectively. Female. Length of idiosoma 1 054 [mu]m,
   Width 763 [mu]m. Anterior dorsal shield with 21 pairs of setae, F1, D1,
   D3 and M2 long and pilose, M2 the longest, remaining setae short and
   simple, ET1 and ET2 minute, M3 separated from the shield. Posterior
   dorsal shield with 19 pairs of setae, of which 2 pairs long and pilose,
   remains short and simple. Presternal shields 1 pair. Sternal shield with
   3 pairs of setae and 2 pairs of pores. MSt and the 3rd pair of pores on
   metasternal shields. Genital shield with 1 pair of setae. Endogynium
   circular, with 1 pair of small denticles at posterior margin, 1 large
   tooth on one side. Ventro-anal shield distinctly contracted backward,
   with 7 pairs of ventral setae and 3 perianal setae, simple but posterior
   ventral setae pilose. Ad situated at level of middle of anus, both Ad
   and PA slightly shorter than anus. Peritreme reaching to anterior part
   of coxa I anteriorly. Leg II with 2 short spurs on femur. Tarsus with 4
   apical spines respectively. The new species is near to Gamasodes sinicus
   Tian et Gu, 1991 and Gamasodes tongdensis Li, Yang et Chen, 1999, but in
   deutonymph of the new species dorsal setae D1 and D3 pilose, all femur,
   genu, tibia and-tarsus of leg II with spurs; however in the latter 2
   species D1 and D3 simple, tibia of leg II without spur. Holotype
   deutonymph, paratypes 1 [female] and 2 deutonymphs, under human
   excrement soil, from Jingyuan County (35[degree] 26' N, 106[degree] 24'
   E), Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, 20 July 2011. The new species is
   named after collected locality of type specimens.
C1 Ma Li-Ming; Chinese Base Control & Prevent Plague & Brucellos, Baicheng
   City, Jilin Province, 137000, China, China.
EM lmmabc@msn.com
SC Zoology
SN 1005-9628
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Gamasodes jingyuanensis; Parasitus simplendogynii [Ningxia Hui /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Gamasodes jingyuanensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Ningxia Hui, P. 78]. 
   Parasitus simplendogynii (Acari): [Sp nov, Ningxia Hui, P. 76]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14907026430

DT Article
TI Discovery of the genus Ophionyssus Megnin in China and description of a
   new species (Acari: Mesostigmata: Macronyssidae).
AU Ma Li-Ming (lmmabc@msn.com) 
   Bai Xue-Li
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 21
IS 2
PS 83-86
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 1
U2 3
AB A new species of the genus Ophionyssus Megnin is described in the
   present paper. The genus is recorded from China for the first time.
   Ophionyssus sellisternalis sp. nov. (Figs. 1-10) Female. Length of
   idiosoma 763 [mu]m, width 495 [mu]m. Dorsum covered by two dorsal
   shield. Anterior dorsal shield large, 538 [mu]m long and 323 [mu]m wide,
   with 12 pairs of setae. Posterior dorsal shield very small, 65 [mu]m
   long and 65 [mu]m wide, without setae. Dorsal cuticle setae about 40
   pairs. Sternal shield saddle-shaped, with 2 pairs of sternal setae and 2
   pairs of pores, St3 lying on cuticle behind the shield, MSt lacking.
   Genito-ventral shield tapering, Vl1 situated on cuticle beside the
   shield. Anal shield pear-like, 3 perianal setae subequal to anus in
   length. Peritreme short, reaching to anterion part of coxa III
   anteriorly. Ventral cuticle setae about 25 pairs. Chela scissors-shaped.
   Male. Length of idiosoma 602 [mu]m, width 323 [mu]m. Holodorsal shield
   581[mu]m long and 301 [mu]m wide, setae short. Sterno-genital shield
   narrow, 3 pairs of sternal setae and 2 pairs of pores situated on the
   shield, metasternal setae lacking, genital setae on cuticle off the
   shield. Anal shield pear-like, Ad lying at level of posterior margin of
   anus, both Ad and PA subequal to anus in length. Peritreme reaching to
   anterior part of coxa III anteriorly. Spermatodactyl of chela
   club-shaped. The new species is similar to Ophionyssus eremiadis Naglov
   et Naglova, 1960 and Ophionyssus mabuyae Till, 1957, but in female of
   the new species anterior dorsal shield longer, with 12 pairs of setae on
   the shield, setae length subequal; while anterior dorsal shield of O.
   eremiadis with 9 pairs of setae, F2 distinctly longer than other setae;
   anterior dorsal shield of O. mabuyae shorter, with 8 pairs of setae.
   Holotype [female], ex cave of lizard, from Pingluo County (38[degree]
   55' N, 106[degree] 32' B),Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, 17 Sep. 2009.
   Paratypes 1 [male], same habitat and locality as holotype, 10 Oct. 2009.
   9 protonymphs, same habitat and locality as holotype, 17 Apr. 2010 to 8
   May 2010. Type specimens are deposited in the Entomology Gallery,
   Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology, Academy of Military Medical
   Sciences, Beijing. The new species is named after sternal shield
   (sternalis) saddle-shaped (selli-).
C1 Ma Li-Ming; Chinese Base Control & Prevent Plague & Brucellos, Baicheng
   City, Jilin Province, 137000, China, China.
EM lmmabc@msn.com
SC Zoology
SN 1005-9628
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ophionyssus [China /  / New record]. 
   Ophionyssus sellisternalis [Ningxia Hui /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Ophionyssus (Acari): [New record]. 
   Ophionyssus sellisternalis (Acari): [Sp nov, Ningxia Hui, P. 83].

TI Description of Pachylaelaps ningxiaensis sp nov (Acari: Mesostigmata:
   Pachylaelaptidae).
AU Ma Li-Ming (lmmabc@msn.com) 
   Bai Xue-Li
   Xing Zhong-Wu
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 21
IS 2
PS 87-89
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Pachylaelaps is described in the present
   paper. Pachylaelaps ningxiaensis sp. nov.( Figs. 1-4) Female. Length of
   idiosoma 516-570 (av. 536) [mu]m, width 323-355 (av. 341) [mu]m. Dorsal
   shield almost covering entire dorsum, 505-559 (av. 525) [mu]m long and
   312-344 (av. 330) [mu]m wide. Dorsal shield setae 30 pairs, long and
   simple, but F1 shorter, F2 very short, S8 (19 [mu]m) distinctly shorter
   than S7 (75 [mu]m), S8 : S7 = 1 : 4. Sterno-metastemal shield weakly
   reticulated on surface, bearing 4 pairs of setae. Anterior part of
   genito-ventral shield distinctly contracted, fissure between
   genito-ventral and peritrematal shields very broad, posterior margin of
   the shield convex, with 2 pairs of setae. Anal shield triangular, Ad
   situated behind level of anterior margin of anus, both Ad and PA longer
   than anus. Peritreme reaching to anterior part.or anterior margin of
   coxa II anteriorly. Metapodal shields club-shaped, distant from
   peritrematal shield. Tectum with about 6 bifurcate spines at distal
   margin, lateral margins with many small denticles. Tarsus II with a
   spine. The new species is similar to Pachylaelaps volkovae Goncharova et
   Koroleva, 1974 and Pachylaelaps brackuperitrematus Koroleva, 1977, but
   in the new species dorsal setae long, its end near or reaching to or
   beyond base of next seta; fissure between genito-ventral and
   peritrematal shields very broad. In the latter 2 species dorsal setae
   short, its end distant from base of next seta; fissure between
   genito-ventral and peritrematal shields narrow. Holotype [female],
   paratypes 8 [female] [female], off scarabaeid beetle, from Yanchi County
   (37[degree] 50' N, 107[degree] 28' E), Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, 29
   May 2010. Type specimens are deposited in the Entomology Gallery,
   Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology, Academy of Military Medical
   Sciences, Beijing. The new species is named after collected locality of
   type specimens.
C1 Ma Li-Ming; Chinese Base Control & Prevent Plague & Brucellos, Baicheng
   City, Jilin Province, 137000, China, China.
EM lmmabc@msn.com
SC Zoology
SN 1005-9628
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Pachylaelaps ningxiaensis [Ningxia Hui /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Pachylaelaps ningxiaensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Ningxia Hui, P. 87].

   [mu]m. Dorsal shield covering dorsum and extending to venter,
   reticulations are composed of small circular projections, bearing 6
   pairs of long stout pilose setae and about 10 pairs of short simple
   setae. Sternal shield rectangular, posterior margin concave, with 3
   pairs of setae. Metastemal setae on oval metasternal shields. Genital

TI New records of Gamasid mites from China(2) (Acari: Mesostigmata).
AU Ma Li-Ming (lmmabc@msn.com) 
   Lin Jian-Zhen
   Zhang Yan-Xuan
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 21
IS 2
PS 92-97
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 2
AB 1 Lasioseius frankbakkeri Faraji et Karg, 2005 Newly recorded species
   from China. Specimens 3 [female] [female], ex bird's nest, from Guangze
   (27[degree] 33' N, 117[degree] 20' E), Fujian Province, 18 Oct. 2007; 5
   [female] [female], ex moss and plant litter, from Shaowu (27[degree] 22'
   N, 117[degree] 29' E), Fujian Province, 22 Oct. 2007. 2 Lasioseius
   reticulatus Bhattacharyya, 1968 Newly recorded species from China.
   Specimen 1 [female], ex moss, from Dali (25[degree] 46' N, 100[degree]
   09' E), Yunnan Province, 3 Nov. 2005. 3 Iphidozercon reticulatus

DT Article
TI Distribution of Sea Urchins (Echinodermata: Echinoidea) around Cape
   Bansho, Wakayama, Japan, in 2000 and 2011.
AU Ohgaki, Shun-ichi
   Ishida, So (iso@mus-nh.city.osaka.jp) 
   Kobayashi, Takayuki
   Chogyoji, Daiya
SO Japanese Journal of Benthology
VL 67
IS 1
PS 1-8
PD November 2012
PY 2012
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The distribution of sea urchins (Echinodermata, Echinoidea), and changes
   therein over the course of a decade, were investigated around Cape
   Bansho, which marks the southern limit of Tanabe Bay, Japan
   (33[degree]42' N, 135[degree]20' E). Censuses were carried out once each
   in 2000 and 2011, using a semi-quantitative timed search technique on
   both occasions. Fourteen species of sea urchin were recorded in the two
   survey years, of which 64% were tropical Indo-Pacific species.
   Echinostrephus aciculatus, Anthocidaris crassispina, and Stomopneustes
   variolaris were more abundant in the intertidal than subtidal zone. In
   contrast, Echinometra sp. A, Toxopneustes pileolus, and Diadema setosum
   were more abundant in the subtidal zone than intertidally. The densities
   of Echinometra mathaei, Echinometra oblonga, and Stomopneustes
   variolaris were higher on more exposed shores whereas those of
   Echinometra sp. A and Mespilia globulus were higher on more sheltered
   shores. The present results concerning Echinometra species and wave
   exposure are consistent with previous reports from Okinawa. From 2000 to
   2011 there was a contraction in the ranges of Mespilia globulus, Diadema
   setosum, and Stomopneustes variolaris, all of which are tropical
   species, but the range of the warm-temperate species Anthocidaris
   crassispina remained constant. Environmental and biological evidence
   around Tanabe Bay suggests that climatic events such as a severe winter
   and typhoons were responsible for the decline of the three tropical
   species between 2000 and 2011.
C1 Ishida, So; Kyoto Univ, Grad Sch Sci, Kyoto, 6068502, Japan, Japan.
EM iso@mus-nh.city.osaka.jp
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1345-112X
BD Ecology; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Echinoidea [Population dynamics /  / long term study] [Distribution
   within habitat /  / ] [North Pacific / Japan, Honshu, Wakayama, Cape
   Bansho / ]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata
OR Echinoidea (Echinodermata).

TI Ammonite Aptychi from the Lower Jurassic (Toarcian) near Whitby, North
   Yorkshire, UK.
AU Lomax, Dean R. (skalidis7@hotmail.com) 
   Hyde, Benjamin G.
SO Proceedings of the Yorkshire Geological Society
VL 59
IS 2
PS 99-107
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Ammonite Aptychi from the Lower Jurassic of Port Mulgrave near Whitby,
   U. K., are reported for the first time in association with ammonites of
   the Family Hildoceratidae, Subfamily Harpoceratinae. The Aptychi are
   preserved in shale, varying in their completeness and exhibiting a range
   of sizes, but are identified as Cornaptychus sp. and cf. Lamellaptychus
   sp. Some Cornaptychus specimens are preserved with ammonites identified
   as Tiltoniceras antiquum. The Aptychi, especially Cornaptychus, are
   comparable with Aptychi associated with ammonites of the Harpoceratinae
   elsewhere, notably in the Posidonia Shale of Toarcian age in Germany.
   The ammonite Aptychi were further analysed using an Environmental
   Scanning Electron Microscope (ESEM) in order to determine their
   composition and assess whether this might have implications for their
   occurrence and preservation potential compared with that of the ammonite
   shells.

   DN1 2AE, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

DT Article
TI Earliest record of Platychoerops (Primates, Plesiadapidae), a new
   species from Mouras Quarry, Mont de Berru, France.
AU Boyer, Doug M. (douglasmb@gmail.com) 
   Costeur, Loic
   Lipman, Yaron
SO American Journal of Physical Anthropology
VL 149
IS 3
PS 329-346
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Plesiadapids are extinct relatives of extant euarchontans (Primates,
   dermopterans, and scandentians), which lived in North America and Europe
   during the Paleocene and Early Eocene. The only genus of plesiadapid
   whose species are absent from Paleocene strata is Platychoerops.
   Further, Platychoerops is the only group found in sediments post-dating
   the Paleocene-Eocene boundary (PEB) by a substantial period of time
   based on large samples. It is also substantially different from other
   plesiadapids in dental features thought to reflect ecology. Its
   evolution has been linked to the rapid global climate change and faunal
   turnover marking the PEB. Platychoerops and Plesiadapis tricuspidens
   have been reconstructed as members of a single lineage by some authors.
   We describe a specimen (right p3-m3) that we attribute to a new species,
   Platychoeropsantiquus, from the unequivocally Paleocene (MP6) Mouras
   Quarry of Mont de Berru, France. It has strong morphological affinities
   to Platychoerops daubrei yet co-occurs with many specimens of
   Plesiadapis tricuspidens, as well as the plesiadapid Chiromyoides
   campanicus. The existence of a species of Platychoerops prior to the PEB
   decouples the evolution of Platychoerops from the climate change and
   faunal turnover event associated with the PEB. Furthermore, the
   co-occurrence of Platychoerops with P. tricuspidens refutes the idea of
   a single lineage for these taxa. Instead, Platychoerops may be more
   closely related to North American Plesiadapis cookei (a previous
   alternate hypothesis). We suggest character displacement in a Paleocene
   immigrant population of P. cookei resulting from competition with
   sympatric P. tricuspidens, as a likely scenario for the evolution of
   Platychoerops. Am J Phys Anthropol, 2012. (C) 2012 Wiley Periodicals,
   Inc.
C1 Boyer, Doug M.; Duke Univ, Dept Evolutionary Anthropol, Box 90383, Biol
   Sci Bldg, Durham, NC, 27708-0383, USA, USA.
EM douglasmb@gmail.com
SC History &Philosophy of Science; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology;
   Paleontology
SN 0002-9483; 1096-8644
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Animals and man;
   Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Platychoerops [History of zoology / History of discoveries /
   systematics; earliest record] [Evolution /  / ] [France / Mont de Berru,
   Mouras Quarry / ] [Palaeogene /  / ]. 
   Platychoerops antiquus [France /  / new species] [Palaeocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Primates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Primates, Plesiadapidae
OR Platychoerops - Charlesworth 1854 (Plesiadapidae): [Fossil]. 
   Platychoerops - Charlesworth 1855 (Plesiadapidae): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 341; Fossil]. 
   Platychoerops antiquus (Plesiadapidae): [Sp nov, France, Palaeocene, P.
   341; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Seasonal population dynamics and the genetic structure of the mosquito
   vector Aedes aegypti in Sao Paulo, Brazil.
AU Campos, Melina
   Spenassatto, Carine
   da Graca Macoris, Maria de Lourdes
   Paduan, Karina dos Santos
   Pinto, Joao
   Martins Ribolla, Paulo Eduardo (pribolla@ibb.unesp.br) 
SO Ecology and Evolution
VL 2
IS 11
PS 2794-2802
PD November 2012
PY 2012
UR http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/%28ISSN%292045-7758/issue
   s
AW http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ece3.392/pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 33
AB Population genetic studies of insect vectors can generate knowledge to
   improve epidemiological studies focused on the decrease of pathogen
   transmission. In this study, we used nine SNPs across the Aedes aegypti
   genome to characterize seasonal population variations of this important
   dengue vector. Mosquito samples were obtained by ovitraps placed over
   Botucatu SP from 2005 to 2010. Our data show that, regardless of the
   large variation in mosquito abundance (deduced from the number of eggs
   obtained from ovitraps), the effective population size remained stable
   over the years. These results suggest that Ae. aegypti is able to
   maintain a sufficiently large active breeding population during the dry
   season to keep genetic frequencies stable. These results open new
   perspectives on mosquito survey and control methods.

TI Manta rays in the Marquesas Islands: first records of Manta birostris in

AB Based on direct observations of free-ranging specimens, the giant manta
   ray Manta birostris is reported from the Marquesas Islands, the first
   sighting in French Polynesia. Sightings of its sister species, the reef
   manta ray Manta alfredi, are also reported at the most easterly location

   notes on their distribution are also reported. (C) 2012 The Author

DT Article
TI Terrestrial support of zebra mussels and the Hudson River food web: A
   multi-isotope, Bayesian analysis.
AU Cole, Jonathan J. (colej@caryinstitute.org) 
   Solomon, Christopher T.
SO Limnology and Oceanography
VL 57
IS 6
PS 1802-1815
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 96
AB The Hudson River is a strongly heterotrophic system in which the
   invasive zebra mussel (Dreissena polymorpha) comprises >90% of total
   metazoan biomass. Using a Bayesian mixing model, with isotope ratios of
   C, N, and H, and four basal resources (phytoplankton, benthic algae,
   submersed aquatic vegetation (SAV), and terrestrial inputs), we
   estimated the reliance of 10 consumers on each resource. Copepods,
   Bosmina, and herring (Alosa aestivalis) relied 40-60% on phytoplankton
   primary production; amphipods and young-of-year white perch (Morone
   spp.) relied heavily on benthic algae (50-60%). Terrestrial detritus was
   an important resource for oligochaetes, zebra mussels, chironomids, and
   Bosmina sp., for which median estimates of reliance were between 40% and
   60%. The dual reliance of zebra mussels on terrestrial detritus and
   phytoplankton production, combined with their high biomass, along with
   the significant terrestrial support of several other consumers,
   indicates that terrestrial detritus supports a significant portion of
   the Hudson River food web. Nonetheless, given that particulate and
   dissolved organic matter pools are heavily dominated (60-80%) by
   terrestrial detritus, it is clear that selectivity by consumers for
   autochthonous organic matter is generally high. Despite its large
   biomass and productivity, we did not find strong evidence for support of
   the food web by SAV.
C1 Cole, Jonathan J.; Cary Inst Ecosyst Studies, Millbrook, NY, USA, USA.
EM colej@caryinstitute.org
RI Solomon, Chris/E-6284-2014; Cole, Jonathan J/G-4566-2011
OI Solomon, Chris/0000-0002-2850-4257; Cole, Jonathan J/0000-0003-4633-7402

SN 0024-3590

   Atlantic Ocean

   [North Atlantic / USA, New York, Hudson River estuary / ]. 
   Phytomastigophorea [Biomass /  / ] [Productivity / Primary productivity
   / ] [Food webs /  / ] [Predators /  / ] [North Atlantic / USA, New York,
   Hudson River estuary / ].

TI FIELD-COLLECTED PERMETHRIN-RESISTANT AEDES AEGYPTI FROM CENTRAL THAILAND
   CONTAIN POINT MUTATIONS IN THE DOMAIN IIS6 OF THE SODIUM CHANNEL GENE
   (KDR).
AU Srisawat, Raweewan (raweewan.sri@mahidol.ac.th) 
   Komalamisra, Narumon
   Apiwathnasorn, Chamnarn
   Paeporn, Pungasem
   Roytrakul, Sittiruk
   Rongsriyam, Yupha
   Eshita, Yuki
SO Southeast Asian Journal of Tropical Medicine and Public Health
VL 43
IS 6
PS 1380-1386
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB One of the mechanisms responsible for pyrethroid resistance in
   mosquitoes is mutations in domain IIS6 of voltage-gated sodium channel
   gene (kdr). Aedes aegypti larvae were collected from the central
   provinces of Thailand (Bangkok, Prachin Buri and Ratchaburi) and
   colonized until they became adults. Partial fragment of kdr of
   permethrin-resistant mosquitoes were amplified by RT-PCR and sequenced.
   Among the four nucleotide mutations detected, two mutations resulted in
   two amino acid substitutions, S(TCC) 989 P(CCC) and V(GTA)1016 G(GGA).
   Among 94 permethrin-resistant mosquitoes, the SS genotype (SS/VV) was
   found to predominate (n = 74), followed by SR (SP/VG) (n = 15) and RR
   (PP/GG) genotypes (n = 5), with the resistant allele frequency ranging
   from 0.03 to 0.17. As pyrethroid insecticides are currently being
   advocated for use in Thailand, investigations of pyrethroid resistance
   in other regions of the country are needed to prevent potential
   cross-resistance among different types of insecticides.
C1 Srisawat, Raweewan; Mahidol Univ, Fac Trop Med, 420-6 Ratchawithi Rd,
   Bangkok, 10400, Thailand, Thailand.
EM raweewan.sri@mahidol.ac.th

SN 0125-1562

   [Mutation / Point mutations / ] [Fertilizers and pesticides /  / ]
   [Thailand / Bangkok, Prachin Buri & Ratchaburi / ].

AN ZOOR14905017206
DT Article
TI New communal roosting tradition established through experimental
   translocation in a Neotropical harvestman.
AU Teng, Brian
   Dao, Sylvie
   Donaldson, Zoe R.
   Grether, Gregory F. (ggrether@ucla.edu) 
SO Animal Behaviour
VL 84
IS 5
PS 1183-1190
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 26
AB 'Tradition' has been invoked to explain instances in which animals
   aggregate repeatedly in the same locations for no apparent reason, but
   alternative explanations, such as cryptic habitat selection, are
   difficult to rule out. Distinguishing among these hypotheses requires
   field experiments. We studied a species of harvestman (Prionostemma sp.)
   that forages solitarily at night and forms roosting aggregations in
   spiny palms by dawn. Aggregations have formed repeatedly in the same
   sites for over a decade, and yet the aggregation sites do not appear to
   differ from unused sites in tree characteristics or microclimate.
   Previous research suggested that the harvestmen find aggregation sites
   by detecting chemicals left behind by conspecifics. If so, it should be
   possible to establish new aggregation sites simply by moving harvestmen
   to new locations. We carried out such an experiment and, as predicted,
   release sites attracted harvestmen at much higher rates than did matched
   control sites. Most individuals that came to release sites were new
   recruits, and one site continued to attract several harvestmen for at
   least 7 days, suggesting that a new roosting tradition was established.
   We also revisited the question of whether any other factors, besides
   past usage, predict site use. Among sites used by the harvestmen, the
   size of the aggregations was strongly predicted by microclimate and
   spiny palm characteristics. Together these findings support the
   hypothesis that attraction to conspecific cues is the primary mechanism
   responsible for the long-term stability of aggregation sites, while also
   suggesting that site characteristics play a previously unrecognized
   role. Understanding how site traditions develop may have direct
   applications in conservation. (C) 2012 The Association for the Study of
   Animal Behaviour. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Grether, Gregory F.; Univ Calif Los Angeles, Dept Ecol & Evolutionary
   Biol, 621 Charles E Young Dr S, Los Angeles, CA, 90095, USA, USA.
EM ggrether@ucla.edu
RI Donaldson, Zoe/O-8311-2018; Grether, Gregory F./F-6286-2011
OI Donaldson, Zoe/0000-0001-6699-7905; 
SC Zoology; Behavioral Sciences; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry
SN 0003-3472; 1095-8282
BD Behaviour; Social behaviour; Activity patterns; Ecology; Habitat
   utilization; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; Central America
DE Prionostemma [Aggregating behaviour /  / Conspecific attractions]
   [Roosting / Roosting tradition / ] [Habitat preference /  / ] [Forest
   and woodland / Rain forest / ] [Nicaragua / Refugio Bartola / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Opiliones
OR Prionostemma (Opiliones). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14905017206
OA Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14905016684
DT Article
TI The diverse Cretaceous neobatrachian fauna of South America:
   Uberabatrachus carvalhoi, a new frog from the Maastrichtian Marilia
   Formation, Minas Gerais, Brazil.
AU Baez, Ana M.
   Gomez, Raul O. (baez@gl.fcen.uba.ar) 
   Ribeiro, Luiz C.B.
   Martinelli, Agustin G.
   Teixeira, Vicente P.A.
   Ferraz, Mara L.F.
SO Gondwana Research
VL 22
IS 3-4
PS 1141-1150
PD November 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Herein we report on a new anuran genus and species, Uberabatrachus
   carvalhoi, from exposures of the Marilia Formation (Maastrichtian) at
   the well-known fossil site "Ponto 1 do Price" near Peiropolis, Uberaba,
   Brazil. The holotype consists of an articulated partial skeleton
   characterized by a broad, well-ossified skull lacking dermal
   ornamentation, eight procoelous presacral vertebrae, and posteriorly
   deflected, cylindrical sacral diapophyses; these features, together with
   the possible presence of a discrete palatine, are consistent with
   neobatrachian affinities. It clearly differs from the neobatrachian
   Baurubatrachus, also from the Marilia Formation, in having a skull
   lacking exostosis and with a different temporal architecture, among
   other features. It also differs from the still unnamed neobatrachian
   recovered from the Adamatina Formation in the presence of paired
   frontoparietals with narrow supraorbital flanges in the anterior orbital
   region and maxilla-squamosal contact. The new frog is not referable to
   any of the neobatrachian taxa known from the Aptian-Albian Cram
   Formation owing to different cranial features (e.g., position of the jaw
   articulation, relative width of the braincase, and morphology of the
   frontoparietal). With respect to the extant neobatrachians in the
   context of recent phylogenetic hypotheses, the cylindrical sacral
   diapophyses of Uberabatrachus contrast with the dilated diapophyses
   occurring in australobatrachian hyloids and microhyloid ranoids, whereas
   the procoelous presacral column is unlike the diplasiocoelous condition
   of most other ranoids. This evidence together with the combination of
   features of Uberabatrachus suggests a placement among nobleobatrachian
   hyloids, although this combination is not shared with any extant or
   extinct species for which skeletal information is known. From the
   foregoing we conclude that Uberabatrachus represents a new
   nobleobatrachian taxon, a record that reinforces the hypothesis of a
   diversified neobatrachian fauna in South. America by the Cretaceous and
   is consistent with the previous proposal that neobatrachian early
   diversification is related to the breakup of Gondwana. (C) 2012
   International Association for Gondwana Research. Published by Elsevier
   B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Gomez, Raul O.; UBA, FCEyN, Pab 2,Ciudad Univ,C1428EHA, Buenos Aires,
   DF, Argentina, Argentina.
EM baez@gl.fcen.uba.ar

DT Article
TI Wyeomyia exallos, a new species of sylvatic mosquito (Diptera:
   Culicidae) from Brazil.
AU Rocha, Glauber Pereira
   Lourenco-de-Oliveira, Ricardo
   Motta, Monique de Albuquerque (mmotta@ioc.fiocruz.br) 
SO Memorias do Instituto Oswaldo Cruz
VL 107
IS 7
PS 928-934
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Wyeomyia exallos, a new mosquito species from Atlantic Forest of
   southeastern Brazil, is described based on morphological characters of
   the adult female, male, male genitalia, pupa and fourth-instar larva.
   The morphological characters of Wy. exallos sp. nov. are compared with
   those of different subgenera of Wyeomyia as well as of species without
   subgeneric position. It is proposed that the new species should be
   placed in genus Wyeomyia Theobald without subgeneric assignment.

DT Article
TI Morphological and molecular characterization of Teleaulax gracilis sp
   nov and T. minuta sp nov (Cryptophyceae).
AU Laza-Martinez, Aitor (aitor.laza@ehu.es) 
   Arluzea, Jon
   Miguel, Irati
   Orive, Emma
SO Phycologia
VL 51
IS 6
PS 649-661
PD Nov 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 2
U2 29
AB Teleaulax is a genus of delicate cryptophytes that are common and
   sometimes abundant in marine samples. Previous to this study, only three
   species (Teleaulax acuta, T. amphioxeia and T. merimbula) were known in
   the genus. Here, two new species were described from strains isolated
   from plankton samples collected at the seaward end of the
   Nervioi-Ibaizabal River estuary (south-eastern Bay of Biscay). They were
   examined by light microscopy and scanning and transmission electron
   microscopy, and the nuclear 18S rDNA was sequenced to infer the
   molecular phylogeny. The species of this genus have been distinguished
   by size, shape (especially of the cell anterior and posterior), swimming
   behaviour, morphology of the posterior band and the relative extension
   of the furrow. The most characteristic traits of Teleaulax gracilis sp.
   nov. were the cell anterior, that was only slightly rostrate, and the
   shape of the cell posterior, which tapered off gradually in form of a
   wedge and finished in a pointed antapex sustained by a V-shaped band.
   Teleaulax minuta sp. nov., with a length of 5-6.8 [mu]m, is the smallest
   within the genus and lacks a posterior band. Common features shared with
   other congeners are, among others, the long furrows, the more or less
   rostrate cell anteriors and tapered posteriors, a sheet-like internal
   periplast component thinner than the plasma membrane and the thylakoids
   arranged in stacks of three.

   Cryptomonadida

   (marine), P. 652]. 
   Teleaulax minuta - Laza-Martinez 2012 (Cryptomonadida): [Sp nov, Spain
   (marine), P. 653].

DT Article
TI Diversity, Evolution and Molecular Systematics of the
   Psalteriomonadidae, the Main Lineage of Anaerobic/Microaerophilic
   Heteroloboseans (Excavata: Discoba).
AU Panek, Tomas
   Silberman, Jeffrey D.
   Yubuki, Naoji
   Leander, Brian S.
   Cepicka, Ivan (ivan.cepicka@centrum.cz) 
SO Protist
VL 163
IS 6
PS 807-831
PD November 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 31
AB We isolated and cultivated 31 strains of free-living heterolobosean
   flagellates and amoebae from freshwater, brackish, and marine sediments
   with low concentrations of oxygen. Phylogenetic analysis of small
   subunit (SSU) rDNA showed that the strains constitute a single clade,
   the Psalteriomonadidae. According to combined light-microscopic
   morphology plus molecular phylogeny, our isolates belong to seven
   species and five genera, from which three species and two genera are
   new. In addition, previously described anaerobic species Percolomonas
   descissus and Vahlkampfia anaerobica are transferred to the
   Psalteriomonadidae. We identified a flagellate stage of Monopylocystis
   visvesvarai which was reported to produce only amoebae. Two
   environmental sequences previously obtained from acidic environments
   belong to the Psalteriomonadidae as well, suggesting a broad ecological
   importance of the Psalteriomonadidae. The ultrastructure of two
   psalteriomonadid species was also studied. Unifying features of the
   Psalteriomonadidae are acristate mitochondrial derivates, flagellates
   with a ventral groove and four flagella, and a harp-like structure in
   the mastigont. A new overall classification of the Psalteriomonadidae is
   proposed. Our data show that the Psalteriomonadidae are much more
   diverse than previously thought and constitute the main anaerobic
   lineage within the Heterolobosea. [copyright] 2011 Elsevier GmbH. All
   rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Evolutionary Insights from Bat Trypanosomes: Morphological,
   Developmental and Phylogenetic Evidence of a New Species, Trypanosoma
   (Schizotrypanum) erneyi sp nov., in African Bats Closely Related to
   Trypanosoma (Schizotrypanum) cruzi and Allied Species.
AU Lima, Luciana
   da Silva, Flavia Maia
   Neves, Luis
   Attias, Marcia
   Takata, Carmen S.A.
   Campaner, Marta
   de Souza, Wanderley
   Hamilton, Patrick B.
   Teixeira, Marta M.G. (mmgteix@icb.usp.br) 
SO Protist
VL 163
IS 6
PS 856-872
PD November 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 19
AB Parasites of the genus Trypanosoma are common in bats and those of the
   subgenus Schizotrypanum are restricted to bats throughout the world,
   with the exception of Trypanosoma (Schizotrypanum) cruzi that also
   infects other mammals and is restricted to the American Continent. We
   have characterized trypanosome isolates from Molossidae bats captured in
   Mozambique, Africa. Morphology and behaviour in culture, supported by
   phylogenetic inferences using SSU (small subunit) rRNA, gGAPDH
   (glycosomal glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase) and Cyt b
   (cytochrome b) genes, allowed to classify the isolates as a new
   Schizotrypanum species named Trypanosoma (Schizotrypanum) erneyi sp.
   nov. This is the first report of a Schizotrypanum species from African
   bats cultured, characterized morphologically and biologically, and
   positioned in phylogenetic trees. The unprecedented finding of a new
   species of the subgenus Schizotrypanum from Africa that is closest
   related to the America-restricted Trypanosoma (Schizotrypanum) cruzi
   marinkellei and T. cruzi provides new insights into the origin and
   evolutionary history of T. cruzi and closely related bat trypanosomes.
   Altogether, data from our study support the hypothesis of an ancestor
   trypanosome parasite of bats evolving to infect other mammals, even
   humans, and adapted to transmission by triatomine bugs in the
   evolutionary history of T. cruzi in the New World. [copyright] 2012
   Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Molecular Phylogeny of Tintinnid Ciliates (Tintinnida, Ciliophora).
AU Bachy, Charles
   Gomez, Fernando
   Lopez-Garcia, Purificacion
   Dolan, John R.
   Moreira, David (charles.bachy@u-psud.fr) 
SO Protist
VL 163
IS 6
PS 873-887
PD November 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 19
AB We investigated the phylogeny of tintinnids (Ciliophora, Tintinnida)
   with 62 new SSU-rDNA sequences from single cells of 32 marine and
   freshwater species in 20 genera, including the first SSU-rDNA sequences
   for Amphorides, Climacocylis, Codonaria, Cyttarocylis, Parundella,
   Petalotricha, Undella and Xystonella, and 23 ITS sequences of 17 species
   in 15 genera. SSU-rDNA phylogenies suggested a basal position for
   Eutintinnus, distant to other Tintinnidae. We propose Eutintinnidae fam.
   nov. for this divergent genus, keeping the family Tintinnidae for
   Amphorellopsis, Amphorides and Steenstrupiella. Tintinnopsis species
   branched in at least two separate groups and, unexpectedly, Climacocylis
   branched among Tintinnopsis sensu stricto species. Tintinnopsis does not
   belong to the family Codonellidae, which is restricted to Codonella,
   Codonaria, and also Dictyocysta (formerly in the family Dictyocystidae).
   The oceanic genus Undella branched close to an undescribed freshwater
   species. Metacylis, Rhabdonella and Cyttarocylis formed a well supported
   clade with several Tintinnopsis species at a basal position.
   Petalotricha ampulla and Cyttarocylis cassis SSU-rDNA and ITS sequences
   were identical or almost identical. Therefore, we propose Cyttarocylis
   ampulla comb. nov. for them. Intensive use of single-cell isolation and
   sequencing revealed unexpected complexity in the evolutionary history of
   these relatively well-studied ciliates. Notably, the diversity of
   freshwater forms suggests multiple marine-freshwater invasions.
   [copyright] 2012 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Micriamoeba tesseris nov gen. nov sp.: A New Taxon of Free-living
   Small-sized Amoebae Non-permissive to Virulent Legionellae.
AU Atlan, Daniele
   Coupat-Goutaland, Benedicte
   Risler, Arnaud
   Reyrolle, Monique
   Souchon, Maud
   Briolay, Jerome
   Jarraud, Sophie
   Doublet, Patricia
   Pelandakis, Michel (michel.pelandakis@univ-lyon1.fr) 
SO Protist
VL 163
IS 6
PS 888-902
PD November 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB Investigation of soil amoebae in 11 cooling towers allowed us to isolate
   a major unknown small-sized amoeba population (SZA). However, SZA did
   not appear to be specific to cooling tower ecosystems since they are
   also a major amoeba population found in muds isolated from different
   points of a water treatment plant. The SSU-rDNA sequences from SZA
   strains did not match any known database sequences, suggesting that SZA
   constitutes a new amoeba taxon. We isolated and further described one of
   the SZA that we named Micriamoeba tesseris. The phylogenetic analyses
   showed that Micriamoeba tesseris belongs to the Amebozoa and branched
   together with genus Echinamoeba + Vermamoeba vermiformis. Phylogenetic
   analyses within the Micriamoeba group distinguished different subgroups
   of Micriamoeba strains according to their origin, i.e. cooling tower or
   mud. Although Micriamoeba are able to feed on viable E. coli cells, they
   do not uptake virulent Legionella pneumophila strains, thus enabling
   them to avoid infection by Legionella. Consequently, Micriamoeba is not
   directly involved in L. pneumophila multiplication. However, an indirect
   role of Micriamoeba in Legionella risk is discussed. [copyright] 2012
   Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

   France.

   Patricia/L-9480-2014; COUPAT, Benedicte/G-5488-2019

   Sophie/0000-0001-5750-0215; Doublet, Patricia/0000-0001-5848-4317;
